About Park Development P. J.' S P
Continued from Page 1

negative opinions. Park-users
argue that Wyman Park is one
of the last pieces of land in the
area that has not been disrupted
by urbanization. Since the land
has not been properly maintained or landscaped by the city, it
is, in large part, an untamed
wood with several unusual
species of flora and fauna.
Residents objected to the fact
that no preliminary environmental impact study is
known to have been done.
Several park-users have claimed to have seen mallards,
hawks, orioles, and even a fox
in the park. Concern over
displacing these animals by any
attempt at land improvement is
widespread.
Councilman Anthony J.
Ambridge, who represents
Wyman Park citizens, expressed dissatisfaction with the plans
in the July 19 Sun. "Open
space is unique and it's not
renewable. I just don't want to
see it developed. It's just a
beautiful, beautiful park."
A second major worry is the
possibility of disturbing the
stream which runs behind the
BIA field. Since the area is a
floodplain, neighbors are concerned about changes in the
water level resulting from
future development, and want
to know who will be responsible for any damage as a result
of future floods.
Fears were also expressed
that the University would use
the land for secret, potentially
hazardous, or military research.
Bowie answered this worry with
a resounding "No." "The
university has an absolute
policy against any classified
research on this campus," he
maintained.
Residents also pointed out
that the proposed facilities
would increase traffic in an
already congested area. The City is now forming a task force
to examine these grievances and
to look for a just settlement.
Hopkins considered obtaining Wyman Park after Mayor
Schaefer, during a budget hearing earlier this year, informally proposed the idea of making
the land available to the
University to expand the Space
Telescope Science Institute.
Viewing the mayor's remarks as

a promise of support, Hopkins
officials proceeded and had architects build a scale model of
the proposed research facilities.
This model was available for inspection by area residents last
August.
In the July 19 Sun, Dagmar
Miller, president of the Wyman
Park Community Association,
expressed the neighborhood's
discontent. "I can't blame
Hopkins for doing what it's doing, and I don't argue with the
value of Hopkins as a major
employer and asset to the
neighborhood. What really
angers me is the mayor baiting
them into asking for the rest of
the park," she explained.
Hopkins officials believe that
the many benefits the development will bring outweigh the
negative aspects. The current
proposal will provide more jobs
and the community will reap
these economic advantages.
Much of the land will remain
untouched, according to
Bowie, and Hopkins will take
on the responsibility of maintaining it. "We really don't
think the rest of this [land] is
buildable, but by owning it, we
think we can upgrade it and
really make it usable for
everyone," he added.
Hopkins is presently considering only two building sites
on the property and the chance
of future development is very
slim. "I just don't think that
[further construction] is in the
cards," commented Bowie.
"The topography just does not
lend itself to doing anything
reasonable." The steep slopes
in part of the park and the flow
of the stream limit building to
a site on the extreme northern
end of Wyman Park and to the
south, near Olin Hall, according to Bowie.
Another possibility, which
the mayor is trying to prevent
is for Hopkins to build outside
of Baltimore City. Expansion is
necessary and while the University would prefer to extend the
Homewood Campus, "there is
a clear possibility that we would
look to places like Montgomery
County as a place to do
research," commented Bowie.
The land which is now
Wyman Park has had a long
and controversial history, and
in fact once belonged to the
University. In 1902, six promi-

nent Baltimoreans gave 181
acres to establish the
Homewood Campus and this
included what is now Wyman
Park. According to the Hamburger Archives, the following
year, the trustees of Johns
Hopkins gave the city 52 acres,
which were viewed as unneeded, to enlarge the park.
Later that decade, the
University sold 8 more acres to
the city at a nominal price to
further extend the park. In
1926, another six acres were
donated for the building of the
art museum. Ironically,
Hopkins gave the city more
land for Wyman Park than did
its original benefactor, William
Wyman.
In 1960, Milton Eisenhower
attempted to reacquire Wyman
Park to build new dormitories,
parking lots, and to relocate the
athletic field. At that time,
Parks Board president Frank
Marino publicly described the
land as "the least desirable" in
the park system. Although the
Board unanimously voted to
sell Hopkins the land, community outcries forced revision
of the transaction. Instead of
the 73 acres originally promised, Hopkins was allowed to
purchase only the thirty acres
betweeen Stoney Run and San
Martin Drive.
Further neighborhood opposition was voiced when the
University then started to build
on the land it had purchased. In
1980, with the construction of
Olin Hall, area residents protested the disturbance of the
open space (even though
Hopkins owned the land).
The controversy continued
this past summer as concerned
citizens organized demonstrations to protest the sale of
public park land. As a result,
Mayor Schaefer is backing
away from the support he
originally promised. Bowie
asserted, however, that the purchase of Wyman Park is "by
no means a dead issue. The
University is willing to work
toward a compromise on this
thing that will give us more
buildable land."
Area residents also plan to
continue efforts to block the
transfer. In any event the legal
battle over the park will probably entail a long, tedious
process.

by Jon Stempel

Two of the four area majors have
undergone changes recently: one of the
programs died; the other was revamped.
Both moves were good ones.
The reforms are the result of committees set up last year to study all four area
majors: quanitative sciences, natural
sciences, humanities and social and
behavioral sciences.
The committees grew, then Associate
Dean of Graduate and Undergraduate
Studies Lucien Brush said at the time,
out of concerns about all the area majors. Department Chairmen, he said,
were worried area majors had no
guidance.
Among students, the complaints were
much harsher. The area majors were
often said to be easy ways to get a degree
without doing much work. Often they
were.
That was most unfortunate, for in
many ways the area majors are the truest
and best kind of undergraduate major.
They provide a rough focus (the social
sciences, say, or the humanities) while
allowing students a great deal of flexibility. That's really what an undergraduate
education is all about.
The committees, then, had an important task: to restructure the area majors
such that they become a more viable part
of the curriculum. All four of the panels
reported over the summer, but changes
have actually been implemented in only
two of the programs: quanitative studies
and natural sciences.
The change for quantitative studies
was certainly the most drastic. The program was abolished. That isn't much of
a loss, particularly considering that, as
the committee noted in its report, only

four undergraduates currently list quantitative studies as their major.(The program's demise won't affect them; it only applies to students entering this fall.)
Having around an area major with few
or no students could only serve to
discredit the other three. Far better to do
a little housecleaning and create three
strong and vital programs.
The changes in the Natural Science
Area Major attempt to do just that. Requirements for 300-level courses have
been increased, a language requirement
has been added and requirements for
specific science and math courses have
been strengthened. The program has
always been fairly large (harboring,
among other people, a lot of pre-meds),
but it should now be fairly strong as well.
One last note: while the work of the
committees which examined the area majors has been commendable, a complaint
from last spring ought to be reiterated.
There should have been students on the
panels. When they were appointed, it
was said committees of faculty members
and administrators were best able to
review curriculum. Student input would
be most welcome, we were all assured,
but the committees themselves would be
closed to students. That is absurd. It's
obvious that you can't expect significant
student input unless students are actually on the committees.
Still, the committees were right to bag
the quantitative studies area major and
strengthen the natural science one. It will
be interesting to see what changes are
made in the other two area majors. If
sensible decisions are made again, the
area majors could take their place as the
best programs at Hopkins.

Did you ever have to write a
dull paper on a dull topic? Not
the sort of paper on the alleged
cocaine use of Peter Ueberroth,
but the sort of paper for which
you have to show that you have
read many chapters of dense
material.
The following process illustrates how you can make
writing a dull paper seem fun.
You should start about two
days before the paper's due
date, enough time for you to
finish but not so much time that
you'll actually begin to understand what you write.
For the sake of this article,
let's say that the paper is due
one Monday October morning
at 9:00 a.m. The course is titled "Dentistry after Marco
Polo" (it's an advanced
course), and the professor gave
you a topic that he says you can
really sink your teeth into—
tooth decay of the thirteenth
century. You begin:
Saturday, 11:00 a.m.—
Wake up. It's too early. Fall
back asleep.
Saturday, 1:00 p.m.— Wake
up for real. Realize that you
have to write the tooth decay
paper by Monday, but if the
football team is home, watch it
play. If the team is away, play
poker with your friends. Cheat.
Saturday, 4:30 p.m.— Begin
to think about your paper.
Saturday, 4:31 p.m.—Think
about your paper.
Saturday, 4:32 p.m.— Think
about the party at St. Elmo's.
Forget the paper.
Saturday, 5:30 p.m.—
Realize,that you should be
writing your paper. But you
have to eat. Eat at the Terrace

Room, whether you're on the
meal plan or not.
Saturday, 6:00 p.m.— Now
that you've eaten at ARA, you
have a wealth of ideas for your
paper on tooth decay.
Saturday, 6:30 p.m.— Start
writing your paper. Well, try
anyway.
Saturday, 7:30 p.m.— It's
been a long week. Take a nap.
Saturday, 10:00 p.m.— Go
to St. Elmo's.
Sunday, 1:30 a.m.— Watch
a re-run of The Munsters.
Sunday, 2:00 a.m.— Go to
sleep.
Sunday, 11:00 a.m.— Wake
up. Turn on the radio. Listen to
Jerry Falwell.
Sunday, 11:01 a.m.— Back
to bed.
Sunday, 12:30 p.m.— Wake
up. Realize that you have to
finish writing your paper.
Procrastinate.
Sunday, 1:00 p.m.— Watch
the Giants win.
Sunday, 4:00 p.m.— Watch
the Jets lose.
Sunday, 7:00 p.m.— Finish
writing your paper. Type it.
Sunday, 9:00 p.m.— Enjoy
yourself. You've earned it.
This program will make a
dull paper seem more fun to
write. You will get a good grade
because you will always be
writing when your mind is open
and refreshed. If you can stick
to this program, you will do
well.
I have only one problem with
this process. The problem affects me, to varying degrees, a
few times each year. If you're
like me, add:
Monday, 11:00 a.m.— Flunk
calculus test that you forgot
about.

A Better Symposium
The decline in the last few years of the
Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium has
been a much-discussed topic recently.
Happily, though, that trend seems to
have reversed—this year's symposium
looks stronger than the last three or four.
A glance back through decade-old
programs reveals symposiums peppered
with big-name speakers. The topics were
also more interesting then, less strictly
political, more interesting: "The Pen as
Weapon" and "The Question of
Freedom."
But the last few years have seen the
symposium go downhill. Topics have
become far too specific, and, concomitantly, speakers have become too
academic: experts in their own fields but
generally people with little name
recognition.
This year, at least some of that seems
to have changed. The symposium will be
kicked off by George McGovern, a man
who isn't an expert in anything but who
should "pack 'em in." Later -speakers
will include James Schlessinger, twice a

cabinet officer, and Edward Rowny, currently one of the Reagan administration's top arms negotiators. Both are
well-known men who should draw some
attention.
It's true that there will also be some
duds—an unnamed Soviet official, who
ought to be about as interesting as Soviet
officials always are (i.e. a yawner), Han
Xu, the Chinese Ambassador to the
United States, who doesn't exactly have
a big following, and Paul Nitze, who is
one of the most interesting men alive but
who has spoken at Hopkins far too
often—but in general the quality of the
speakers seems much improved.
An ingenious format change, whereby
differing views on an issue will be offered
in successive lectures, should also enliven
the series.
The topic—arms control—is still .a bit
limited for our tastes, but the symposium
in general looks improved. The trick now
will be to continue the improvement for
the next few years.

Why perform a play whose

Italian operas or why

Kabuki. Somehow it is not

being said. "Sure," an opponent might say, "But the opera

the Kabuki has beauty and
grace. Aristophanes is a comic
and most of the plays' wit is
found in the dialogue." True,
but it is still funny. And there
is a certain amount of good
music and grace and beauty as
well.
Of course there is the
"other" reason at work here
too; that is, it is an effort to
restore to life a play and a
language—a culture, for that
matter.There is definitely an
"archaeological fascination"
involved with watching a play
performed in Ancient Greek. It
is a bit like handling an old
treek urn—you think to
yourself, "Gee, some,,ne 2500
years ago handled this urn
too." While watching the play
you think,"Gee, someone 2400

years ago watched this play
too."
Aristophanes
wrote
Thesmophoriazusae, or "The
Women Celebrating the
Thesmophoria," in 411 B.C.
He was a contemporary of both
Euripides, the playwright of
whom he makes fun, and
Socrates, who is lampooned in
Aristophanes' The Clouds.
Certainly it is thrilling to be immersed in a genuine cultural artifact from the Golden Age of
Greece.
The play as performed by the
King's College players is not
primarily, however, an
academic exercise. Certainly
Thesmophoriazusae is not one
of Aristophanes' better-known
plays or better plays period.
There is a sense in which they
have tried primarily to hit on
universal themes. The play is
billed
as
a
"fashion
spectacle—thrills—
feminism—dialectics—sexual
deviancy—laughs—laughs—
laughs." The main context is a
battle of the sexes, certainly not
irrelevant to the present age,
with some characters left in the
middle—corresponding to the
present tide of androgyny. It is
most effective in revealing that
even in 5th Century Greece,
women were asserting their

authority. With these themes at
the forefront the plot and
dialogue are just secondary
components.
Not that the play doesn't
have a plot. Simply put, the action is as follows: Euripides is
very worried that the assembly
of women at the Festival of
Demeter and Persephone will
seek revenge on him for his
unflattering presentation of
their sex. Euripides and his
cousin Mnesilochus go to the
very effeminate dramatist
Agathon to convince him to infiltrate the assembly (since he
already looks like a woman)
and defend Euripides. Agathon
refuses and Mnesilochus goes
instead, clean-shaven and wearwig.
Agathon's

this production. Not only did
everyone have to learn their
lines in Greek, they also had to
recite them convincingly
(although with British accents.)

could be. Furthermore they
spiced up the humor a bit by
adding modern props, such as
a scooter for EuripidesMenelaus, and modern sound
effects, such as EuripidesMenelaus crashing his scooter.

numbers were quite nice, if not
authentic (though who knows?)

Lady Harriers Roll
by Jeffrey A. Lee
It was a warm pleasant day
last Tuesday. One of those days
when you think summer will
stay in Baltimore for just one
more week. That day, the
women's cross country team
traveled downtown to compete
against division II school, The
University of Maryland in
Baltimore County (UMBC).
Getting off the bus, the lady
Jays were all smiles. They had
confidence in their hearts, and
wings on their feet. They could
not lose.
For the lady harriers it was a
quick, satisfying meet. They
zipped in and they zipped out.
All that remained was a stunned UMBC squad muttering to
themselves, "What 'appened?"
The Magnificent Seven had
struck again.
Leading from the gun, senior
Maureen Shea had the arduous
task of setting pace while correctly negotiating the course.
The first mile was downhill,
and many of the harriers blazed through in sub-6 minute
miles. Following Shea's lead
were Molly Bardsley, Suzi
McGinn, and co-captain/Orgo
lab student extraordinaire
Cecilia King.
On the second mile, the runners dropped off their earlier
rate as the course leveled off.
Nevertheless, the pace remained quick throughout the race as
Shea broke the tape in 19:03.
Behind Shea were Bardsley in
18:26, McGinn in 18:34, King
in 18:49 and Tami Oki in 19:09.
Rounding out the top finishers
were Sindee Gozansky and
Amita Kim, in 7th and 8th
places respectively.
The Magnificent Seven had
managed the best score possible
of 15 points by having 5 runners finish the fast course
before the first runner from
UMBC crossed the line. If not
for this lone UMBC runner
coming in 6th place, the Jays
would have recorded a shutout.
For those who are perplexed
about the intricacies of cross
country scoring, think of the
Jays' feat as equivalent to a

Dwight Gooden no hitter that
is ruined in the bottom of the
ninth by a base-hit.
Indicative of the Jays'
outstanding performance were
the fast times run. Helped by a
quick course, this is the first
meet that any Hopkins runner ran sub 20:00 for a 3.0 mile
course, let alone seven runners.
Also occurring at this meet
were the setting of many personal records such as McGinn's
18:34 for the course.
Obviously, this year's squad
has considerably more talent
than in previous years. Running here last year, King was first
for the Jays in 18:51; this year,
however,the co-captain ran two
seconds faster than last and only finished fourth. The
renaissance in Hopkins' crosscOuntry is due to the sudden
presence of senior Shea as well
as the appearance of frosh
McGinn and Bardsley.
Top runner for the Jays,
Shea is an emotional one whose
reaction to competition is nervousness. Fortunately, Shea is
able to use this tension to her
advantage by converting it into energy that creates a scorching pace.
Shea is followed closely by
Bardsley, who Coach Gary
Green describes as being the
"classic cross-country runner."
Bardsley is a tough competitor
who constantly adapts to the
ever-changing conditions on the
course. Joining Bardsley is
fellow frosh Suzi McGinn.
McGinn, who is new to the
sport, has established her competitive edge through years of
track experience in New York
state.
With such a group of
newcomers spearheading the
Magnificent Seven, the Jays are
looking forward to this Saturday when they face strong
teams from Swarthmore and
Haverford, as well as a team
from Cedar Crest. This is one
of the harrier's few home meets
(what a bargain!), so go out
and cheer the Jays at 1:00 p.m.
at the Athletic Center. The

Two of the four area majors have
undergone changes recently: one of the
programs died; the other was revamped.
Both moves were good ones.
The reforms are the result of committees set up last year to study all four area
majors: quanitative sciences, natural
sciences, humanities and social and
behavioral sciences.
The committees grew, then Associate
Dean of Graduate and Undergraduate
Studies Lucien Brush said at the time,
out of concerns about all the area majors. Department Chairmen, he said,
were worried area majors had no
guidance.
Among students, the complaints were
much harsher. The area majors were
often said to be easy ways to get a degree
without doing much work. Often they
were.
That was most unfortunate, for in
many ways the area majors are the truest
and best kind of undergraduate major.
They provide a rough focus (the social
sciences, say, or the humanities) while
allowing students a great deal of flexibility. That's really what an undergraduate
education is all about.
The committees, then, had an important task: to restructure the area majors
such that they become a more viable part
of the curriculum. All four of the panels
reported over the summer, but changes
have actually been implemented in only
two of the programs: quanitative studies
and natural sciences.
The change for quantitative studies
was certainly the most drastic. The program was abolished. That isn't much of
a loss, particularly considering that, as
the committee noted in its report, only

four undergraduates currently list quantitative studies as their major.(The program's demise won't affect them; it only applies to students entering this fall.)
Having around an area major with few
or no students could only serve to
discredit the other three. Far better to do
a little housecleaning and create three
strong and vital programs.
The changes in the Natural Science
Area Major attempt to do just that. Requirements for 300-level courses have
been increased, a language requirement
has been added and requirements for
specific science and math courses have
been strengthened. The program has
always been fairly large (harboring,
among other people, a lot of pre-meds),
but it should now be fairly strong as well.
One last note: while the work of the
committees which examined the area majors has been commendable, a complaint
from last spring ought to be reiterated.
There should have been students on the
panels. When they were appointed, it
was said committees of faculty members
and administrators were best able to
review curriculum. Student input would
be most welcome, we were all assured,
but the committees themselves would be
closed to students. That is absurd. It's
obvious that you can't expect significant
student input unless students are actually on the committees.
Still, the committees were right to bag
the quantitative studies area major and
strengthen the natural science one. It will
be interesting to see what changes are
made in the other two area majors. If
sensible decisions are made again, the
area majors could take their place as the
best programs at Hopkins.

Did you ever have to write a
dull paper on a dull topic? Not
the sort of paper on the alleged
cocaine use of Peter Ueberroth,
but the sort of paper for which
you have to show that you have
read many chapters of dense
material.
The following process illustrates how you can make
writing a dull paper seem fun.
You should start about two
days before the paper's due
date, enough time for you to
finish but not so much time that
you'll actually begin to understand what you write.
For the sake of this article,
let's say that the paper is due
one Monday October morning
at 9:00 a.m. The course is titled "Dentistry after Marco
Polo" (it's an advanced
course), and the professor gave
you a topic that he says you can
really sink your teeth into—
tooth decay of the thirteenth
century. You begin:
Saturday, 11:00 a.m.—
Wake up. It's too early. Fall
back asleep.
Saturday, 1:00 p.m.— Wake
up for real. Realize that you
have to write the tooth decay
paper by Monday, but if the
football team is home, watch it
play. If the team is away, play
poker with your friends. Cheat.
Saturday, 4:30 p.m.— Begin
to think about your paper.
Saturday, 4:31 p.m.—Think
about your paper.
Saturday, 4:32 p.m.— Think
about the party at St. Elmo's.
Forget the paper.
Saturday, 5:30 p.m.—
Realize,that you should be
writing your paper. But you
have to eat. Eat at the Terrace

Room, whether you're on the
meal plan or not.
Saturday, 6:00 p.m.— Now
that you've eaten at ARA, you
have a wealth of ideas for your
paper on tooth decay.
Saturday, 6:30 p.m.— Start
writing your paper. Well, try
anyway.
Saturday, 7:30 p.m.— It's
been a long week. Take a nap.
Saturday, 10:00 p.m.— Go
to St. Elmo's.
Sunday, 1:30 a.m.— Watch
a re-run of The Munsters.
Sunday, 2:00 a.m.— Go to
sleep.
Sunday, 11:00 a.m.— Wake
up. Turn on the radio. Listen to
Jerry Falwell.
Sunday, 11:01 a.m.— Back
to bed.
Sunday, 12:30 p.m.— Wake
up. Realize that you have to
finish writing your paper.
Procrastinate.
Sunday, 1:00 p.m.— Watch
the Giants win.
Sunday, 4:00 p.m.— Watch
the Jets lose.
Sunday, 7:00 p.m.— Finish
writing your paper. Type it.
Sunday, 9:00 p.m.— Enjoy
yourself. You've earned it.
This program will make a
dull paper seem more fun to
write. You will get a good grade
because you will always be
writing when your mind is open
and refreshed. If you can stick
to this program, you will do
well.
I have only one problem with
this process. The problem affects me, to varying degrees, a
few times each year. If you're
like me, add:
Monday, 11:00 a.m.— Flunk
calculus test that you forgot
about.

A Better Symposium
The decline in the last few years of the
Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium has
been a much-discussed topic recently.
Happily, though, that trend seems to
have reversed—this year's symposium
looks stronger than the last three or four.
A glance back through decade-old
programs reveals symposiums peppered
with big-name speakers. The topics were
also more interesting then, less strictly
political, more interesting: "The Pen as
Weapon" and "The Question of
Freedom."
But the last few years have seen the
symposium go downhill. Topics have
become far too specific, and, concomitantly, speakers have become too
academic: experts in their own fields but
generally people with little name
recognition.
This year, at least some of that seems
to have changed. The symposium will be
kicked off by George McGovern, a man
who isn't an expert in anything but who
should "pack 'em in." Later -speakers
will include James Schlessinger, twice a

cabinet officer, and Edward Rowny, currently one of the Reagan administration's top arms negotiators. Both are
well-known men who should draw some
attention.
It's true that there will also be some
duds—an unnamed Soviet official, who
ought to be about as interesting as Soviet
officials always are (i.e. a yawner), Han
Xu, the Chinese Ambassador to the
United States, who doesn't exactly have
a big following, and Paul Nitze, who is
one of the most interesting men alive but
who has spoken at Hopkins far too
often—but in general the quality of the
speakers seems much improved.
An ingenious format change, whereby
differing views on an issue will be offered
in successive lectures, should also enliven
the series.
The topic—arms control—is still .a bit
limited for our tastes, but the symposium
in general looks improved. The trick now
will be to continue the improvement for
the next few years.

Lady Harriers Roll
by Jeffrey A. Lee
It was a warm pleasant day
last Tuesday. One of those days
when you think summer will
stay in Baltimore for just one
more week. That day, the
women's cross country team
traveled downtown to compete
against division II school, The
University of Maryland in
Baltimore County (UMBC).
Getting off the bus, the lady
Jays were all smiles. They had
confidence in their hearts, and
wings on their feet. They could
not lose.
For the lady harriers it was a
quick, satisfying meet. They
zipped in and they zipped out.
All that remained was a stunned UMBC squad muttering to
themselves, "What 'appened?"
The Magnificent Seven had
struck again.
Leading from the gun, senior
Maureen Shea had the arduous
task of setting pace while correctly negotiating the course.
The first mile was downhill,
and many of the harriers blazed through in sub-6 minute
miles. Following Shea's lead
were Molly Bardsley, Suzi
McGinn, and co-captain/Orgo
lab student extraordinaire
Cecilia King.
On the second mile, the runners dropped off their earlier
rate as the course leveled off.
Nevertheless, the pace remained quick throughout the race as
Shea broke the tape in 19:03.
Behind Shea were Bardsley in
18:26, McGinn in 18:34, King
in 18:49 and Tami Oki in 19:09.
Rounding out the top finishers
were Sindee Gozansky and
Amita Kim, in 7th and 8th
places respectively.
The Magnificent Seven had
managed the best score possible
of 15 points by having 5 runners finish the fast course
before the first runner from
UMBC crossed the line. If not
for this lone UMBC runner
coming in 6th place, the Jays
would have recorded a shutout.
For those who are perplexed
about the intricacies of cross
country scoring, think of the
Jays' feat as equivalent to a

Dwight Gooden no hitter that
is ruined in the bottom of the
ninth by a base-hit.
Indicative of the Jays'
outstanding performance were
the fast times run. Helped by a
quick course, this is the first
meet that any Hopkins runner ran sub 20:00 for a 3.0 mile
course, let alone seven runners.
Also occurring at this meet
were the setting of many personal records such as McGinn's
18:34 for the course.
Obviously, this year's squad
has considerably more talent
than in previous years. Running here last year, King was first
for the Jays in 18:51; this year,
however,the co-captain ran two
seconds faster than last and only finished fourth. The
renaissance in Hopkins' crosscOuntry is due to the sudden
presence of senior Shea as well
as the appearance of frosh
McGinn and Bardsley.
Top runner for the Jays,
Shea is an emotional one whose
reaction to competition is nervousness. Fortunately, Shea is
able to use this tension to her
advantage by converting it into energy that creates a scorching pace.
Shea is followed closely by
Bardsley, who Coach Gary
Green describes as being the
"classic cross-country runner."
Bardsley is a tough competitor
who constantly adapts to the
ever-changing conditions on the
course. Joining Bardsley is
fellow frosh Suzi McGinn.
McGinn, who is new to the
sport, has established her competitive edge through years of
track experience in New York
state.
With such a group of
newcomers spearheading the
Magnificent Seven, the Jays are
looking forward to this Saturday when they face strong
teams from Swarthmore and
Haverford, as well as a team
from Cedar Crest. This is one
of the harrier's few home meets
(what a bargain!), so go out
and cheer the Jays at 1:00 p.m.
at the Athletic Center. The
Cross-Country Experience,
